title: Can't generate lmod modules for go, virtual package problem perhaps?
body:
I'm having trouble generating `lmod` modules.  I've reduced my experiment to doing `spack install go` and a freshly spun up CentOS 7 system and then the following.

Here's what I have installed:

```
[hartzelg@delete-me spack]$ spack find
==> 19 installed packages.
-- linux-centos7-x86_64 / gcc@4.8.5 -----------------------------
autoconf@2.69  gettext@0.19.8.1                     libiconv@1.14    ncurses@6.0     tar@1.29
bzip2@1.0.6    git@2.11.0                           libsigsegv@2.10  openssl@1.0.2j  xz@5.2.2
curl@7.50.3    go@1.7.4                             libxml2@2.9.4    pcre@8.39       zlib@1.2.8
expat@2.2.0    go-bootstrap@1.4-bootstrap-20161024  m4@1.4.17        perl@5.24.0
```

I created a `modules.yaml` file like so (based on the [modules tutorial][modules]:

```
[hartzelg@delete-me spack]$ cat ~/.spack/modules.yaml
modules:
  enable::
    - lmod
  lmod:
    hash_length: 0
```

and then tried to refresh the modules like so:

```
[hartzelg@delete-me spack]$ spack module refresh --module-type lmod --delete-tree -y
==> Regenerating lmod module files
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/bin/spack", line 198, in <module>
    main()
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/bin/spack", line 175, in main
    return_val = command(parser, args)
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/lib/spack/spack/cmd/module.py", line 252, in module
    callbacks[args.subparser_name](module_type, specs, args)
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/lib/spack/spack/cmd/module.py", line 236, in refresh
    x.write(overwrite=True)
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/lib/spack/spack/modules.py", line 388, in write
    self.spec.package.setup_environment(spack_env, env)
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/var/spack/repos/builtin/packages/go/package.py", line 108, in setup_environment
    spack_env.set('GOROOT_BOOTSTRAP', self.spec['go-bootstrap'].prefix)
  File "/home/hartzelg/spack/lib/spack/spack/spec.py", line 2284, in __getitem__
    raise KeyError("No spec with name %s in %s" % (name, self))
KeyError: 'No spec with name go-bootstrap in go@1.7.4%gcc@4.8.5+test arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^bzip2@1.0.6%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^curl@7.50.3%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^expat@2.2.0%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^gettext@0.19.8.1%gcc@4.8.5+bzip2+curses+git~libunistring+libxml2+tar+xz arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^git@2.11.0%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^libiconv@1.14%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^libxml2@2.9.4%gcc@4.8.5~python arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^ncurses@6.0%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^openssl@1.0.2j%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^pcre@8.39%gcc@4.8.5+utf arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^perl@5.24.0%gcc@4.8.5+cpanm arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^tar@1.29%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^xz@5.2.2%gcc@4.8.5 arch=linux-centos7-x86_64^zlib@1.2.8%gcc@4.8.5+pic arch=linux-centos7-x86_64'
```

I *think* that what's going on has something to do with `go-bootstrap` being a virtual package, but I'm not sure what to do beyond that.

I don't think that `GOROOT_BOOTSTRAP` is relevant in the finished project, so one solution might be to arrange for it to be present during the bootstrap phase and not afterwards.  I can poke around a bit in that direction.

But it still doesn't seem like module generation should fail in this particular way.



[modules]: http://spack.readthedocs.io/en/latest/tutorial_sc16_modules.html
